en: Upcycling is, a place that we're learning about today is it's it's
programing that we're trying to get more embedded into our overall infrastructure.
We've done a little bit of upcycling initiatives,
through either other designers or coming up
with community events where we invite the community to,
to help us create, some new patterns with us.
Upcycling is something that's quite challenging to scale,
especially when you're dealing with a mixture of different textiles.
And we're we're not in a situation where we have modern materials.
So, we are learning upcycling.
I would say we're not at a state of maturity within upcycling state,
but it is a clear objective for us to figure that out.
So this will be our year to start.
Really working on it.
We do have some great little upcycling projects in the mix.
We have a good way of getting people engaged with the concept of secularity.
Like it makes it really easy to understand.
Yeah.
And we've over the last few years we did some events.
They were called circular by design and we launched these really great events like
if anything, what it did, it was it was essentially a workshop
of sewing machines and patterns, and you could create your own pattern.
And we used previously used materials and you could create your own thing
and apply branding to it.
But at the end of the day, it created conversation.
People started to understand
what their waste meant to the world, how it impacted others.
They also started to understand
what textile waste really meant because it can't be.
It doesn't just erode over time.
You actually have to find a solution for it.
And then, it created a lot of ideas, which was super fun.
So we did it in New York in LA, and it was just
and we've done it through a UK, etc..
So, I think those kind of initiatives are really great to bring in the community
and come up with new concepts.
